themes.title: The Power of Color: Red and Beyond
points: Highlight the reddish-brown earthenware glazed with tin oxide (Chunk 4) and discuss how red tones symbolize vitality, luck, and celebration in Chinese culture.

Compare the bright pinks, greens, and yellows of Peranakan Chinese ceramics (Chunk 5) to the dramatic use of color in stage design, encouraging students to think about how color evokes emotion and meaning.
Engage students in a quick performance exercise: Pretend to be different colors (e.g., red as fiery passion, green as calm nature) and act out their symbolic traits.

themes.title: Stoneware and Drama: Crafting Stories
points: Discuss the origins of stoneware in Mainland Southeast Asia (Chunk 2) and how early artisans used green-glazed ceramics to mimic celadon. Relate this to the idea of imitation and transformation in theater.
Explore the technical process of glazing and firing stoneware, comparing it to the layers of preparation actors go through to bring characters to life.
Ask students to imagine themselves as ancient potters creating stoneware. What story would their ceramic piece tell? Have them share their ideas dramatically.

themes.title: Symbolism in Ceramics: Myth and Meaning
points: Introduce the auspicious symbolism found in Peranakan Chinese ceramics (Chunk 5), such as motifs representing prosperity and happiness. Relate these symbols to myths and legends often used in drama.
Discuss how painted decoration in iron brown or cobalt blue (Chunk 3) adds narrative depth to ceramics, much like costumes and props enhance storytelling on stage.
Lead a quick activity: Have students invent their own symbolic motif and act out its meaning in a short skit.

themes.title: Material Matters: Porcelain and Stoneware
points: Explain the differences between glazed porcelain and stoneware (Chunk 1), emphasizing the craftsmanship and technical skill required to produce these materials.

Discuss how the materials and techniques evolved over time, such as the shift from ivory-glazed vessels to painted decoration (Chunk 3). Relate this to the evolution of dramatic styles in theater history.
Encourage students to think about how materials (e.g., costumes, props, set pieces) influence storytelling in drama. Have them brainstorm how they would use ceramics as props in a play.

themes.title: Performance and Play: Bringing Ceramics to Life
points: Use the guide's clown school background to incorporate playful and performative elements, such as miming the process of creating ceramics or acting out the myths behind the symbols.
Encourage students to interact with the exhibit by imagining themselves as characters from the Peranakan Chinese community or ancient potters, dramatizing their roles.
End the tour with a group activity: Create a short, improvised play inspired by the themes and artworks in the exhibit, incorporating symbolism, color, and materials.
